NEW YORK (AP) — President Donald Trump's personal attorney dropped a pair of libel lawsuits against BuzzFeed and investigation firm Fusion GPS amid the stir caused by an FBI search of the lawyer's files.

He dropped the suits late Wednesday amid a separate legal battle over the seizure of documents and electronic files from his home, office and hotel room last week in a federal investigation of possible financial fraud.
The dossier claims that Cohen met with Russian operatives in Europe for a meeting to "clean up the mess" over disclosures of other Trump associates' reported ties to Russia.
"But given the events that have unfolded, and the time, attention and resources needed to prosecute these matters, we have dismissed the matters, despite their merits."
FILE - In a Monday, April 16, 2018, file photo, Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's personal attorney, center, leaves federal court, in New York.
Federal prosecutors said they can give President Donald Trump's personal lawyer, Cohen, copies of materials seized from him by the FBI by May 11.
"We believe the defendants defamed my client, and vindicating Mr. Cohen's rights was — and still remains — important," he said in a statement.
"Today's news suggests that Donald Trump's personal lawyer no longer thinks an attack on the free press is worth his time," it said.
Michael Cohen had sued in New York City over publication of the unverified dossier detailing alleged ties between Trump and Russia.
"With his decision, it appears that Mr. Cohen can now focus on his many other legal travails," it said.
Cohen's attorney, David Schwartz, said Thursday the decision to abandon the suits was difficult.
Fusion GPS said in a statement that it welcomed Cohen's decision.
In a statement, BuzzFeed called the suit against it meritless.
They notified a New York judge Wednesday.
